abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Primary
            Education Project for Pakistan was marginally satisfactory.
            The project achieved most of its objectives, its impact on
            institutional development was modest, sustainability is
            uncertain at this time, and the performance of both the Bank
            and Borrower was less than satisfactory. Several lessons can
            be learned from this project. First, the tranche approach
            used in this project was unworkable because it was
            inconsistent with the Government's own project planning
            and approval system. Also, a number of the prerequisites for
            effective tranche programming simply were not present.
            Second, the project introduced innovations and techniques
            that were outside the norms and values of the organizations
            administering the project. Finally, insufficient attention
            was paid to management and organizational issues.

display_title.display_title:
Pakistan - Second Primary
            Education Project : Credit 1602 - Credit Agreement - Conformed

abstracts.cdata!:
The main objective of the proposed
            project is to improve the quality of primary education in
            Pakistan.  The proposed project would cover about 14,000
            schools in Sind, Baluchistan and North West Frontier
            Provinces.  Quality improvement would be achieved by more
            effective in-service training and supervision of teachers,
            improved learning materials, the expanded use of assistant
            teachers, improved physical facilities, and greater
            community support.  The success of the proposed project will
            depend mainly on whether teachers can be influenced
            sufficiently to improve the quality of teaching. The project
            would adopt a new approach to teacher training through the
            development of integrated learning modules for teacher
            training and classroom use.
